author: Mattia Gussoni
text: Qualcosa di anomalo sta accadendo sopra al Polo Nord: un riscaldamento improvviso, denominato in termine tecnico Stratwarming, rischia di portare alla rottura il Vortice Polare con conseguenze dirette sul clima europeo già dall'ormai imminente mese di Gennaio. Va fatta una doverosa premessa. Con stratwarming, in meteorologia, si fa riferimento ad un anomalo e intenso riscaldamento della stratosfera terrestre (porzione dell'atmosfera compresa tra i 15 e 50 km sopra la superficie), proprio sopra il Circolo Polare artico, nell'ordine anche di 40/50°C nel giro di pochissimi giorni. Tale riscaldamento, una volta attivatosi, tende gradualmente ad espandersi in direzione dell'alta troposfera, con ripercussioni nelle successive 2/4 settimane: il settore troposferico immediatamente inferiore, infatti, viene costretto a deformarsi (in termine tecnico si parla di "dislocazione del vortice polare") o a rompersi, suddividendosi in 2/3 minimi depressionari distinti ("split del vortice polare"), i quali poi viaggiano, almeno in parte, in direzione delle medie latitudini, provocando ondate di freddo fin sul cuore dell'Europa e anche sull'Italia. PROIEZIONI GENNAIO 2024 Nei prossimi giorni è prevista una fortissima anomalia climatica sopra al Polo Nord, con temperature fino a 57°C in più rispetto a quanto ci si aspetterebbe in questo periodo! L'ingresso di "aria calda" potrebbe destabilizzare non poco il Vortice Polare. Le ripercussioni, nella bassa troposfera non saranno immediate. Anzi, come avviene in genere, ci vorranno almeno 2/3 settimane e quindi si avvertiranno eventualmente verso la metà di Gennaio. Il passato (anche recente come abbiamo visto) ci insegna che queste dinamiche si traducono spesso in movimenti interessanti a scala emisferica, con possibili irruzioni gelide verso l'Europa centrale e successivamente pure verso l'Italia. Da valutare poi il possibile ritorno delle precipitazioni: bisognerà capire in seguito dove si formeranno i minimi depressionari, per individuare le zone maggiormente coinvolte e se ci saranno occasioni per nevicate fino a bassa quota.

author: jpost.com
title: Hamas has reminded us that we are a nation, a family - a mishpacha - The Jerusalem Post
text:
Hamas has reminded us that we are a nation, a family - a mishpacha - opinion I saw the confusion, I saw the fear, but also the unity and determination. Communities formerly at odds over ritual differences, have come together to advocate and demonstrate for Israel. By MICHAEL OREN MARCH 14, 2024 23:41 Updated: MARCH 15, 2024 06:34 Michael Oren speaking at an event. (photo credit: courtesy of Michael Oren) Anybody who’s ever concluded a speaking tour, especially one as long as mine—nine weeks—knows this feeling. Of being in an airport and not being able to say for sure what city it’s in or even the date of the month. All that remains are the impressions which, gathered in a time of desperate war, of a deepening sense of Jewish loneliness, and of skyrocketing antisemitism, are unprecedentedly profound.
In visits to several dozen Jewish communities across North America , I saw a degree of confusion and fear I never before encountered. People unfamiliar with antisemitism now confront it persistently and in multiple forms—in the Jew-hating slurs of pro-Palestinian protestors, in university administrators indifferent to their Jewish students’ plight, to the ovations received by comedians poking fun at Hollywood’s Jews, and filmmakers weaponizing the Holocaust against Israel.
Virtually every Israel supporter I met had lost friends because of that support. Though an occasional heckler accused Israel of causing antisemitism by killing Palestinians—internalizing the antisemitic claim that all Jews everywhere are liable for Israel’s actions—the vast majority of American Jews understood that rampant anti-Zionism merely exposed a latent Jew-hatred that existed well before October 7 . All but a few realized that Israel’s security was directly linked to their own and that the state of American Jewry was severely threatened by attacks on the Jewish state.
Asked repeatedly, “What should we do?” I responded that American Jews could adopt one of three courses. They could remove the mezuzah from their doors, lock themselves in, and ignore all the prejudice outside. They could move to Israel. Or they could stay and fight. They could resist in the Churchillian sense, I explained, on the campuses, in the media, and through their elected officials. And Jews were only beginning to discover the many ways they can fight back.
Recalling the resignation of the presidents of Penn and Harvard, I reminded my listeners of their ability to exact a price from any official who fails to stand up to antisemitism. “Support pro-Israel media initiatives,” I urged them. “Support anti-boycott legislation.” Counterprotestors stand around a demonstration by Harvard Law Students participating in the National Day of Action organized by Law Students for a Free Palestine, a coalition of students from 38 law schools around the country, at Harvard University in Cambridge, Massachusetts, U.S., November 16, 20 (credit: KEN CEDENO/REUTERS) I saw the fear
I saw the confusion, I saw the fear, but also the unity and determination. Communities formerly at odds over ritual differences, have come together to advocate and demonstrate for Israel. Their contributions to Israel-related philanthropies have broken by far all previous records. So, too, has their participation in emergency missions to work on southern Israeli towns, visit wounded soldiers, and show solidarity with the families of the hostages. Bring Them Home dog tags and lapel ribbons are ubiquitous.
“For all the agony and the sorrow,” I observed. “Hamas has reminded us that we are a nation, a people, a family—a mishpacha.” And yet that oneness is threatened by political rifts that can often seem unbridgeable. Liberal audiences, I learned, are liable to interpret as pro-Trump any attempt to challenge the Biden Administration’s criticism of Israel. Conversely, failure to contrast that criticism with the previous president’s support for Israel can, in more conservative settings, evoke anger. The mere mention of the name Benjamin Netanyahu elicits powerful emotions both for and against.
Such reactions can prove frustrating for a speaker, even one who is not an American citizen, who’s striving to remain neutral in the presidential race and representative of the people of Israel rather than its government. My only recourse is to stress the depth and durability of the US-Israel alliance under successive administrations, and defend the policies espoused by virtually all Israelis, irrespective of their politics.
These distinctions may or may not have proven persuasive to individuals on the political fringe, but the bulk of American Jewry, I found, place their commitment to Israel above the partisan fray. They stand with us in Israel and alongside one another in combating antisemitism, countering anti-Zionism, and upholding Israel’s right to defend itself and exist as the Jewish state.
Though I may not, on this last leg of more than two months on the road, know exactly which airport I’m in or what the day of the week is, I’m certain of the message I’ll soon take home. Rarely before have our people been more united and we are not alone. Though the times are dark and the challenges myriad, with the help of an American Jewish community galvanized, mobilized, and ready to act, Israel will ultimately prevail.
Michael Oren , formerly Israel’s ambassador to the United States, Knesset Member, and Deputy Minister for Diplomacy, is the founder of the Israel Advocacy Group and author of the Substack, Clarity.
Related Tags Israel Jewish michael oren The October 7 Massacre

author: 小浪财讯
title: 中证A500ETF基金（159358）跌0.79%，半日成交额1.07亿元|A50_新浪财经_新浪网
text:
6月19日，截止午间收盘，中证A500ETF基金（159358）跌0.79%，报0.999元，成交额1.07亿元。中证A500ETF基金（159358）重仓股方面， 贵州茅台 截止午盘涨0.00%， 宁德时代 跌1.13%， 中国平安 跌0.93%， 招商银行 跌0.70%， 美的集团 跌0.65%， 比亚迪 跌1.40%， 长江电力 跌0.33%， 兴业银行 跌0.08%， 紫金矿业 跌1.44%， 东方财富 跌2.19%。
中证A500ETF基金（159358）业绩比较基准为 中证A500指数 收益率，管理人为大成基金管理有限公司，基金经理为刘淼，成立（2024-11-22）以来回报为0.73%，近一个月回报为-0.02%。
风险提示：市场有风险，投资需谨慎。本文为AI大模型自动发布，任何在本文出现的信息（包括但不限于个股、评论、预测、图表、指标、理论、任何形式的表述等）均只作为参考，不构成个人投资建议。

author: Redacción Nación
title: Así fue el aterrador momento en que un sicario dispara a quemarropa a otros sujetos en una barbería al sur de Bogotá
text: Colombia enfrenta actualmente un complicado panorama de seguridad, especialmente en las principales ciudades como Bogotá, donde esta semana se registró un violento incidente. En un video se puede ver el momento en que un sicario ingresó a una barbería y, sin hacer ruido, se acercó a dos hombres y les disparó a quemarropa . Una de las víctimas estaba cortándole el cabello a un cliente en ese instante.Las cámaras de seguridad captaron al agresor huyendo rápidamente del lugar después de quitarle la vida a ambas personas. Las impactantes imágenes, que muestran a los dos hombres tendidos en el suelo, han alcanzado cerca de 60 mil reproducciones.Sobre el tema, el teniente coronel Germán Gómez, comandante estación policía Ciudad Bolívar: “Frente a los hechos presentados en la localidad de Ciudad Bolívar, específicamente en el barrio Paraíso, en un establecimiento abierto al público, donde un ciudadano sin mediar palabra, arremete contra la vida y la integridad de dos ciudadanos de nacionalidad extranjera, la Policía Nacional se permite informar que al llegar al lugar de los hechos desplazan estos dos ciudadanos hasta centro asistencial donde un parte médico”.Así mismo, dio a conocer que “no revisten gravedad las heridas, la Policía Judicial, el circuito cerrado de televisión con las cámaras del C4 están verificando la trazabilidad para dar con el paradero de este sujeto”.“Es de anotar que estos hechos no tienen indicios que apunten por casos de extorsión”, puntualizó el uniformado. Conductor arrolló a delincuentes que intentaban robarlo en Bogotá Este jueves 22 de agosto, se registró un nuevo incidente de inseguridad en Bogotá. En la intersección de la calle 26 con la carrera 70, en el noroccidente de la capital, un intento de robo terminó de manera violenta cuando un conductor atropelló a dos delincuentes que se desplazaban en motocicleta. Los criminales habían intentado robarle el teléfono móvil a la víctima.En un acto de defensa, el conductor embistió a los asaltantes con su vehículo. Como resultado, uno de los delincuentes quedó atrapado debajo del carro y murió en el lugar. El otro logró escapar, pero fue encontrado poco después con heridas graves y trasladado a un hospital. Este suceso ha generado preocupación entre los residentes del área, quienes están alarmados por el incremento de la inseguridad. Las autoridades están investigando el caso para esclarecer los detalles. El día anterior, miércoles 21 de agosto, otro incidente de inseguridad tuvo lugar en Bogotá, cuando unos delincuentes robaron un carro de valores en la localidad de Los Mártires. La Policía Metropolitana de Bogotá confirmó que, tras recibir el reporte, se activó un operativo que permitió recuperar el vehículo en poco tiempo. Según información preliminar, los delincuentes habrían retenido a los ocupantes del carro de valores y los trasladaron a la localidad de Puente Aranda.Aunque un video muestra el momento exacto en que el vehículo fue recuperado, aún no se conocen todos los detalles sobre el trayecto de los ocupantes y el paradero de los criminales. Fuentes policiales informaron a SEMANA que las cámaras de seguridad sugieren la posible implicación de los ocupantes del carro en el robo, ya que habrían dejado el vehículo abierto y sin seguro mientras se dirigían a un cajero automático cercano, facilitando así el robo.

author: BLITZ
title: Rolling Stones já não vêm à Europa em 2025
text:
A manga europeia da Hackney Diamonds Tour, dos Rolling Stones, seria oficialmente anunciada esta semana, com Lisboa no roteiro, mas a digressão da banda inglesa não vai acontecer devido a questões logísticas
Os 14 concertos previstos na digressão europeia dos Rolling Stones, incluindo uma passagem por Lisboa, a 20 de maio, caíram por terra. A planificação da tournée estava muito adiantada e seria anunciada ainda no decorrer desta semana mas questões logísticas com os três primeiros concertos, em Barcelona e Lisboa, levaram ao cancelamento do projeto. O cancelamento da digressão, que nunca chegou a ser oficialmente anunciada pelos Rolling Stones, não merecerá qualquer comentário por parte da banda.
Relacionados

author: Joseph S. Pete joseph.pete@nwi.com, 219-933-3316
title: Shipwreck becomes Indiana's 2nd underwater nature preserve
text: Indiana's "own Indiana Jones" worked for decades to ensure the shipwreck of the SS Muskegon, one of the finest passenger ships on the Great Lakes in its heyday, would be preserved as Indiana's second Underwater Nature Preserve. On Thursday, amid fanfare in Millennium Plaza, near the mouth of where Trail Creek opens into the great expanse of Lake Michigan, Indiana University Center for Underwater Science and Academic Diving Program Director Charles Beeker saw his work come to fruition. The Muskegon, which was originally known as the Peerless when it was built in Cleveland and launched on the Great Lakes in 1872, was officially preserved as an Underwater Nature Preserve at a ceremony near the Old Lighthouse Museum in Michigan City. It got a plaque and a buoy marking its underwater grave in 30 to 35 feet of water in Lake Michigan about a quarter mile from the shore from Mount Baldy, part of the Indiana Dunes National Park in Michigan City. The Indiana Department of Natural Resources also will offer virtual tours of the shipwreck online for land-lubbers who don't plan to dive to see it. People are also reading… "I've watched as Charlie has become one of the nation's leading underwater archeologists, one of the leading voices of preservation of maritime history, not only in Indiana but around the globe," said Indiana Department of Natural Resources Director Dan Bortner, who grew up diving in quarries in southern Indiana and took his class at IU to learn diving safety. "Being a so-called landlocked state, a place without oceans, one would likely be surprised to learn that Indiana is home to one of the foremost leaders in underwater archeology, Indiana's own Indiana Jones I guess you could say. Diving in this field is a science and an art. You've got have a passion for it. Now Indiana is home to not one but two Underwater Nature Preserves, forever protected as places of unique historic and cultural significance." Indiana is home to more than 300 nature preserves, nearly all of which are on land. In 2013, Beeker helped establish the state's first Underwater Nature Preserve at the site of the shipwreck of the J.D. Marshall, a ship that tragically turned turtle in a gale off the shore of the Indiana Dunes State Park, drowning four crewmen in one of the worst maritime disasters in Indiana history in 1911. "By becoming an Underwater Nature Preserve, the Muskegon will become one of the most highly protected sites in the state," Bortner said. "By becoming an official Underwater Nature Preserve, the Muskegon will be protected for your lifetime, your children's lifetimes and for generations to come. Conservation continues to be a major part of the mission of the DNR. On October 6, 1910, the Muskegon became a tragic part of our Indiana story. On today, July 18, 2024, we come together to officially commemorate that and attach a physical reminder in perpetuity. For those of you who dive, I hope you have a chance to explore this site and discover the wonders it offers. For the rest of us, we'll look down through Lake Michigan's waves and think back on these shipwrecks and this nation's upward climb through a period of immense change and stormy waters." More than 6,000 shipwrecks have gone missing in the Great Lakes, mostly from the heyday of commercial shipping in the 1800s but date as far back as when the French explorer and fur trader René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle piloted the first vessel on the Great Lakes in the 1600s. An estimated 50 shipwrecks lie with the 241 square miles of Lake Michigan that fall within Indiana's boundaries. Beeker has been surveying the Muskegon, a 220-foot-long ship that could carry 1,200 tons of cargo since the 1980s. He helped get it listed on the National Register of Historic Places. "It was the first shipwreck recognized in our waters," he said. "It was the first on the National Register. It and the J.D. Marshall were in shallow water, readily accessible, representative of a maritime heritage not only of Indiana but of the Great Lakes region. They should be open to the public. We have two sites that are Nature Preserves. It adds an extra layer of protection. That means you'll be able to go out to both those sites. They'll be a mooring buoy. They'll be a historic marker identifying it readily seen from Mount Baldy or Crescent Beach identifying it." The SS Muskegon is close to shore and can be reached reached by a beginning diver or even a highly skilled snorkeler. It's also visible from the surface on a day when the water's clear. "They're less than 30 feet deep and accessible," he said. "A lot of Great Lakes divers want to go to the deep wrecks — and there are better wrecks in other areas, you might argue — but I would say the advantage of these two and the reason they're important is they're our wrecks. They're Indiana wrecks. They're open to the public. You can go there and see the limestone plaque we installed yesterday. It's really it's own little park. That's the advantage of being a nature preserve, the management and interpretative materials you can see from the National Park Services and the Indiana Dunes State Park. Again, it's ours. I've worked around California and Florida at various state parks and at National Marine Sanctuaries. I've worked in the Shipwreck Trail in Florida Keys and the Dominican Republic. Now we have this site we're dedicated. I'm proud to be working in our own state." Northwest Indiana has a rich maritime history with a lot of cargo passing through Lake Michigan, said Sam Haskell, assistant director for IU's Center for Underwater Science. It's also visible from the surface on a day when the water's clear. "The Great Lakes are intrinsic to the people and the culture," he said. "You had so much commerce coming out of Chicago, so much commerce coming out of this part of Northern Indiana." The Muskegon was described as one of the finest ships on the Great Lakes when it went into service in 1872, Haskell said. "It served from Chicago to Duluth. It ferried people and cargo all up and down the Great Lakes," he said. "You could have a nice weekend trip aboard the Peerless stateroom and have a wonderful, wonderful (time) while it was also carrying goods." In the time before highways, people took ferries across the Great Lakes that were typically lushly appointed with finely decorated interior salons, gourmet food and live bands. The Muskegon had elegant accommodations with chandeliers, vaulted ceilings, fluted pillars, ornate wood railings and other luxurious furnishings in both its stateroom and cabins. "It was classy," he said. "You could go on board, have a nice meal and drinks and ultimately come back to Chicago or another port city." The ship went on to serve other roles, including as a gambling vessel. It hauled lumber from lumberyards to railroads. It ultimately ended up as a sand sucker barge that sucked sand off the bottom of Lake Michigan and ferried it to railcars so it could be used for construction and manufacturing materials. In 1910, the Muskegon burned down in Trail Creek where it sat for nearly a year. A kerosene spill was suspected. It was stripped of all its sand sucking equipment over time and eventually towed out into Lake Michigan and sunk off the shore by Mount Baldy. "It's been there ever since," Haskell said. "We are very excited to formally dedicate this shipwreck, which is very representative of a swathe of Great Lakes heritage and commerce, as a Nature Preserve." A look back at Northwest Indiana businesses that closed in 2023 A look back at Region businesses that closed in 2023 Beer Geeks, one of the Region's first, most beloved and most influential craft beer bars, closed after more than a decade and is being reimagined as a new concept. [ 88-year-old White Castle in Whiting, one of Chicago area's first, coming down to be replaced with new restaurant](/news/local/88-year-old-white-castle-in-whiting-one-of-chicago-areas-first-coming-down-to/article_63869ea6-1aa6-542b-92c9-bd5d795d4244.html) The landmark 88-year-old castle-shaped White Castle in Whiting is coming down to be replaced with a newer, larger, more modern White Castle restaurant. A longtime staple in downtown Crown Point poured its last drink. The longtime Westforth Sports gun shop is closing. The Silver Line Building Products plant at 16801 Exchange Ave. will be shuttered permanently. Brewfest in Highland will close in what's been called "an end of an era." David's Bridal filed for bankruptcy and could close all stores if no buyer emerges to save it. The 88-year-old Whiting White Castle will be remembered with displays at museums in two different states. For years, the "millionaire's club" met every morning in the corner booth of the historic 88-year-old White Castle at Indianapolis Boulevard and 119th Street in downtown Whiting. The landmark restaurant served its final slider Tuesday. [ Downtown Griffith staple G&G Hobbies left to longtime employee, who's looking for buyer to keep it going](/news/local/downtown-griffith-staple-g-g-hobbies-left-to-longtime-employee-whos-looking-for-buyer-to/article_2e08c647-4ae4-53b6-96e4-57c3dc868718.html) One of Northwest Indiana's most popular and enduring hobby shops is looking for a buyer after the longtime owner died. J&L This N That Consignment Shop, a popular thrift store, closed in downtown Whiting after a run of several years. A Calumet Region institution, Calumet Fisheries on the far South Side of Chicago, is temporarily closed after failing a city health inspection. Just days after reopening after city health inspectors shut it down, Calumet Fisheries suffered a major fire. Pepe's Mexican Restaurant is no mas in Valparaiso. Beer Geeks in Highland rebranded as B-Side Bar & Lounge and then closed within a few months. [ Bed Bath and Beyond to close Valparaiso store and multiple Chicagoland locations, leaving just one Region location left](/news/local/business/bed-bath-and-beyond-to-close-valparaiso-store-and-multiple-chicagoland-locations-leaving-just-one/article_cbe8edf7-f634-5789-b637-9f9981362abd.html) Troubled retailer Bed Bath and Beyond will permanently close its Valparaiso location as it shutters more stores nationwide as it looks to restructure and shrink its footprint to save the struggling business. Peoples Bank has shuttered its branch in downtown Hammond. Viking Artisan Ales will soon pour its last craft beer at its Merrillville taproom. Old Chicago Pizza & Taproom is closing after 15 years at one of Northwest Indiana's most prominent highway interchanges. The Chicago Auto Show, the nation's largest auto show, returns to McCormick Place Saturday, running through Feb. 19. Munster-based Land O'Frost, the packaged lunchmeat giant, is laying off 215 workers in Chicago and shuttering a plant it acquired two years ago. Ginuwine will trot out hits like "Pony" at Festival of the Lakes.

organizations.name: indiana university center for underwater science and academic diving program
